awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Camera-Based Multimodal AI for Health Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will be to mitigate healthcare costs and challenges associated with the nation's growing aging population. The outcome of this project will be a system that enables holistic, accurate, and faster monitoring of elderly people that will 1) improve quality of life and health of senior citizens, 2) address the future nursing shortage, particularly in the geriatric field, and 3) reduce healthcare costs. The proposed technology can impact a wide range of public health applications that require continuous, non-intrusive health monitoring.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project applies real-time computer vision and sensor fusion processing for real-time continuous monitoring and analysis of health-related activities. In addition, this project takes an essential step beyond current solutions by analyzing seniors' group behavior and interactions with objects to determine whether they suffer from loneliness, behavioral disorders, or confusion states. This project utilizes multiple artificial intelligence algorithms to maximize the discriminative power to understand human micro-body motions and thereby create a training framework for personalized behavioral understanding and monitoring. It also proposes an innovative solution to leverage the results of computer vision as attention feedback to thermal sensors to enhance the accuracy and robustness of thermal processing against temperature variations. Furthermore, the project offers an integrative edge-based Internet of Things solution to protect citizens' privacy while providing real-time continuous feedback to responsible personnel. The proposed system offers a novel user experience while protecting personally identifiable information.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This Phase 1 focused on designing and developing AVA, an advanced AI-powered video-based mobile application designed for reliable fall risk assessment of older adults in their living environments. The app is based on STEADI (Stopping Elderly Accidents, Deaths, and Injuries), an initiative developed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to address the burden of falls among older adults. AVA is a software-only solution, leveraging smartphones' built-in cameras and processing power to conduct all necessary intelligent processing tasks. A key feature of AVA is its commitment to user privacy, as it operates without video surveillance and does not store or transfer original videos.

The primary users of AVA are caregivers of older adults, including family members, loved ones, and staff in independent living communities. The application assists caregivers in evaluating mobility factors associated with fall risks in older adults. AVA is designed to be user-friendly, compatible with a wide range of everyday devices, and strongly emphasizes privacy. This approach enables assessments to be carried out without requiring direct supervision by healthcare professionals. The major outcomes of this Phase 1 project include:

 

  1. Designed and developed AI-based video analytics for real-time visual assessment of fall risk and motor function in older adults - This involved creating algorithms to analyze video data to identify potential fall risks and assess motor functions.

  2. Developed a novel AI-integrated mobile application, the AVA app, for routine fall risk assessment of older adults - This integrates the AI algorithms into a user-friendly mobile application, ensures compatibility with various devices, and optimizes the app for efficient performance.

  3. Conducted early user studies and evaluated the user acceptance of AVA for independent at-home use by caregivers and older adults -These studies were crucial in gathering feedback on the app's usability, effectiveness, and overall user satisfaction.

  4. Initiated AVA pilots with independent living communities. These pilots allowed us to test the application in real-world settings and provided valuable insights into its practical use and impact on the target user group.

 

Throughout Phase 1, our efforts were geared towards designing a robust, effective, and user-friendly tool for fall risk assessment, contributing to the promotion of healthier aging among older adults. The successful completion of these objectives laid a solid foundation for further development and refinement of AVA in subsequent phases.

 


 


Last Modified: 03/31/2024
Modified by: Mona Azarbayjani
